name: pipe
description: A powerful text-processing tool for pattern scanning and data extraction.
long_description: The cat command in Linux, short for "concatenate," is  used to display the contents of files directly in the terminal. It reads files sequentially and outputs their contents to the standard output.  It can also be used to combine files or create new ones by redirecting  input. Overall, cat is a simple and essential tool for viewing and manipulating text files in Linux.
details: FILE: The file(s) to display or process. If no file is specified, cat reads from standard input (e.g., keyboard input).
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

name: awk
description: A powerful pattern scanning and processing language.
long_description: The awk command in Linux is a versatile programming language designed for pattern scanning and processing. It is commonly used for extracting and manipulating data from text files or streams. awk processes input line by line, splitting each line into fields based on a delimiter (default is whitespace), and allows users to perform actions based on patterns or conditions.
details: PATTERN: A condition or pattern to match lines in the input.
ACTION: Commands to execute when the pattern matches.
FILE: The file(s) to process. If no file is specified, awk reads from standard input.

options.-F: Specify the field separator (e.g., -F: for colon-separated fields).
options.-v: Assign a value to a variable (e.g., -v var=value).
options.-f: Read the awk script from a file.

name: cat
description: A command to display or concatenate file contents.
long_description: The cat command in Linux, short for "concatenate," is used to display the contents of files directly in the terminal. It reads files sequentially and outputs their contents to the standard output. It can also be used to combine files or create new ones by redirecting input. Overall, cat is a simple and essential tool for viewing and manipulating text files in Linux.
details: FILE: The file(s) to display or process. If no file is specified, cat reads from standard input (e.g., keyboard input).
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

name: kill
description: Send a signal to a process.
long_description: The kill command in Linux is used to send a signal to a process, usually to terminate it. It can be used to stop processes that are running in the background or to send other signals to processes.
details: PID: The process ID(s) to send the signal to.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-n: Specify the signal number to send.

name: less
long_description: The less command in Linux is used to view the contents of files interactively. It allows users to scroll through the file, search for text, and navigate through the file using keyboard commands.
details: FILE: The file(s) to view.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-F: Exit if the output fits on one screen.

name: ln
long_description: The ln command in Linux is used to create hard and symbolic links to files and directories. Hard links are direct references to the file's data, while symbolic links are pointers to the file's location.
details: TARGET: The file or directory to link to.
LINK_NAME: The name of the link to create.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-s: Make symbolic links instead of hard links.
options.-v: Print name of each linked file.

name: ls
long_description: The ls command in Linux is used to list the contents of directories. It provides information about files and directories, including their names, sizes, permissions, and more.
details: FILE: The file(s) or directory(ies) to list.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-h: With -l, print sizes in human readable format.

name: man
description: Display the manual for a command.
long_description: The man command in Linux is used to display the manual pages for commands. It provides detailed information about the command, including its syntax, options, and examples.
details: COMMAND: The command to display the manual for.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-k: Search the short descriptions and manual page names for the keyword.
options.-f: Display only the first page found.
options.-a: Display all pages matching the command.

name: mkdir
long_description: The mkdir command in Linux is used to create directories. It can create single or multiple directories at once and set permissions for the new directories.
details: DIRECTORY: The directory(ies) to create.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-v: Print a message for each created directory.

name: mv
description: Move or rename files and directories.
long_description: The mv command in Linux is used to move or rename files and directories. It can move files to a different directory or rename them within the same directory.
details: SOURCE: The file(s) or directory(ies) to move or rename.
DIRECTORY: The destination directory.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-n: Do not overwrite an existing file.

name: ps
description: Report a snapshot of current processes.
long_description: The ps command in Linux is used to report a snapshot of the current processes. It provides information about the processes running on the system, including their process IDs, user IDs, CPU usage, memory usage, and more.
details: OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-x: Include processes without a controlling terminal.

name: pwd
long_description: The pwd command in Linux is used to print the current working directory. It displays the full path of the directory you are currently in.

options.-L: Print the value of $PWD if it names the current working directory.
options.-P: Print the physical directory, without any symbolic links.

name: rm
long_description: The rm command in Linux is used to remove files or directories. It can delete single files, multiple files, or entire directories.
details: FILE: The file(s) or directory(ies) to remove.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-f: Ignore nonexistent files and arguments, never prompt.
options.-r: Remove directories and their contents recursively.

name: rmdir
long_description: The rmdir command in Linux is used to remove empty directories. It can only delete directories that are empty.
details: DIRECTORY: The directory(ies) to remove.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-v: Output a diagnostic for every directory processed.
options.--ignore-fail-on-non-empty: Ignore each failure that is solely because a directory is non-empty.

name: scp
long_description: The scp command in Linux is used to securely copy files between hosts on a network. It uses SSH for data transfer and provides the same authentication and security as SSH.
details: USER: The user to authenticate as.
SRC_HOST: The source host.
SRC_FILE: The source file.
DEST_HOST: The destination host.
DEST_FILE: The destination file.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

name: sed
description: Stream editor for filtering and transforming text.
long_description: The sed command in Linux is a stream editor used for filtering and transforming text. It can perform basic text transformations on an input stream (a file or input from a pipeline).
details: input-file: The file(s) to process.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-n: Suppress automatic printing of pattern space.
options.-e: Add the script to the commands to be executed.
options.-f: Add the contents of script-file to the commands to be executed.

name: ssh
long_description: The ssh command in Linux is used to securely log into a remote machine and execute commands on it. It is the most common way to access remote Linux servers.
details: USER: The user to authenticate as.
HOST: The remote host to connect to.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-p: Port to connect to on the remote host.
options.-i: File from which the identity (private key) for public key authentication is read.

name: sudo
description: Execute a command as another user.
long_description: The sudo command in Linux is used to execute a command as another user, typically the superuser. It allows users to run programs with the security privileges of another user.
details: COMMAND: The command to execute.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-u: Run the command as a specified user.
options.-b: Run the command in the background.

name: tail
description: Output the last part of files.
long_description: The tail command in Linux is used to output the last part of files. By default, it displays the last 10 lines of each file. It can be used to monitor the end of a file in real-time.
details: FILE: The file(s) to display the last part of.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-f: Output appended data as the file grows.
options.-n: Output the last K lines, instead of the last 10.
options.-q: Never output headers giving file names.
options.-v: Always output headers giving file names.

name: tar
long_description: The tar command in Linux is used to create, maintain, modify, and extract files from an archive file (commonly known as a tarball). It supports various compression methods.
details: FILE: The file(s) to archive or extract.
OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-t: List the contents of an archive.

name: top
long_description: The top command in Linux is used to display real-time information about the system's running processes. It provides a dynamic view of the system's performance, including CPU and memory usage.
details: OPTION: Optional flags to modify the behavior of the command.

options.-n: Number of iterations in batch mode.
options.-p: Monitor only processes with specified process IDs.
